Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Generation and Evaluation of Body Mass Prediction Equations Using Articular Surface Areas of the Primate Tarsus

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
One of the most fundamental descriptors of a species is its body mass, which is strongly related to life history, diet, mode of locomotion, and many other ecological factors. Despite its centrality to a species' ecology, body mass remains difficult to reconstruct reliably from elements that preserve well in the fossil record, specifically teeth and bones. This project will assess the reliability of body mass prediction from dental and skeletal microCT scan measurements using a large sample of specimens with known body masses. The relationships between these measurements and body mass will be examined and compared to previously published results. This project also provides opportunities for collaboration with fellow graduate students, and training of and collaboration with undergraduates. Training will consist of microCT scanning, digital preparation, measurement protocols, and statistical analyses. MicroCT data collected for this project will be made publicly available using a free online repository, permitting wide access to previously unavailable material. Specimens digitized for this study could readily serve as valuable teaching tools.

This project seeks to explore the relationship between body mass and the joint articular surfaces of the tarsus with a focus on a wide range of primate taxa. Tarsal elements will be microCT- or laser-scanned so that joint articular surface areas can be digitally measured. The primary objective is to improve the theoretical foundation for body mass prediction by addressing whether an improved functional understanding of predictor variables (articular surface areas) permits the generation of more reliable body mass prediction equations (BMPEs). This objective will be accomplished by 1) assessing the scaling relationships of different joint articular surface areas relative to body mass in extant taxa, 2) generating novel body mass prediction equations from joint articular surface areas for comparison to previously published BMPEs, and 3) generating novel BMPEs from specimens with associated and longitudinal body mass data for comparison to BMPEs generated from specimens lacking associated body mass data. These analyses will inform two subsequent portions of the study, 1) body mass prediction for a large sample of fossil primates, and 2) a detailed examination of body mass evolution during important stages of primate diversification.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Body mass is one of the most informative descriptors of a species, as it exhibits strong correlations with life history, diet, mode of locomotion, and other physiological and ecological characteristics. However, despite its centrality to a species' ecology, body mass remains difficult to reconstruct reliably from elements that preserve well in the fossil record, specifically teeth and bones. This project achieved two primary objectives: 1) to gauge the reliability of body mass prediction using proxies from different regions of the body, and 2) to investigate several debates surrounding the methodology of body mass prediction.

First, using a large sample of primates and their nearest living relatives, body mass prediction equations were generated from the joint articular surface areas of two bones of the foot (the talus and calcaneus). The accuracy and precision of these novel equations were compared to the accuracy and precision of previously published prediction equations. Results from this study suggest that elements of the weight-bearing skeleton generate more accurate predictions than the dentition.

Second, tests of predictive accuracy were performed using a large and phylogenetically diverse sample of individuals with associated body masses (including Alouatta palliata [mantled howling monkey] from Hacienda La Pacifica, Costa Rica; Pan troglodytes schweinfurthii [eastern chimpanzee] from Gombe Stream National Park, Tanzania; and strepsirrhine primates from the Duke Lemur Center) in order to determine whether prediction equations generated more reliable species mean or individual-specific body masses. Results suggest that predictive accuracy is maximized by using a mean predictor value (and attempting to predict species mean body mass) rather than using an individual’s predictor value (and attempting to predict that individual’s body mass). Even in instances when only an individual predictor value was represented, equations generated more accurate predictions of species mean values than individual-specific values.

Third, the importance of longitudinal change in body mass was evaluated by comparing coefficients of variation for individual and mean body mass of the populations at La Pacifica, Gombe, and the Duke Lemur Center. Individual coefficients of variation were significantly greater than the population coefficients of variation, which suggests that mean body masses are more stable “targets” of prediction.

Finally, the novel prediction equations were applied to a sample of sympatric fossil primates with associated dental and postcranial elements from the Green River Basin of Wyoming (middle Eocene, ~45 million years before the present day). New body mass predictions suggest two pairs of similarly sized primates: Notharctus tenebrosus and Smilodectes gracilis (~2500 grams), and Omomys carteri and Hemiacodon gracilis (~400 grams). This suggests that niche partitioning between these closely related taxa was probably achieved through differences in diets, rather than differences in body mass.
